abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:sec><jats:title>Background</jats:title><jats:p>The muscle Ras (<jats:italic>MRAS</jats:italic>) gene resides on chromosome 3q22.3 and encodes a member of the membrane-associated Ras small GTPase proteins, which function as signal transducers in multiple processes including cell growth and differentiation. Its role in cardiovascular disease is not fully understood yet. In a preliminary study in heterozygous familial hypercholesterolaemia, we identified a locus linking the early onset of coronary artery disease (CAD) to chromosome 3q.22 and elected to sequence the<jats:italic>MRAS</jats:italic>gene using the MegaBACE DNA analysis system. In the present study, we investigated the association of seven single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) at this locus with CAD and its dyslipidaemia-related risk traits in 4,650 Saudi angiographed individuals using TaqMan assays by the Applied Biosystems real-time Prism 7900HT Sequence Detection System.</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Results</jats:title><jats:p>Among the studied SNPs, rs6782181 (<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>= 0.017) and rs9818870T (<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>= 0.009) were associated with CAD following adjustment for sex, age and other confounding risk factors. The rs6782181_GG also conferred risk for obesity (1,764 cases vs. 2,586 controls) [1.16(1.03–1.30);<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>= 0.017], hypercholesterolaemia (1,686 vs. 2,744) [1.23(1.02–1.47);<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>= 0.019], hypertriglyceridaemia (1,155 vs. 3,496) [1.29(1.01–1.45);<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>= 0.043] and low high-density lipoprotein-cholesterol (lHDL-chol) levels (1,935 vs. 2,401) [1.15(1.02–1.30);<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>= 0.023] after adjustment. Additionally, rs253662_(CT+TT) [1.16(1.01–1.32);<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>= 0.030] was associated with lHDL-chol levels. Interestingly, rs253662 (<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>= 0.014) and rs6782181 (<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>= 0.019) were protective against acquiring high low-density lipoprotein-cholesterol (hLDL-chol) levels (<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>= 0.014), while rs1720819 showed similar effects against CAD (<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>< 0.0001). More importantly, a 7-mer haplotype, ACCTGAC (<jats:italic>χ</jats:italic><jats:sup>2</jats:sup>= 7.66;<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>= 0.0056), constructed from the studied SNPs, its 6-mer derivative CCTGAC (<jats:italic>χ</jats:italic><jats:sup>2</jats:sup>= 6.90;<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>= 0.0086) and several other shorter derivatives conferred risk for obesity. hLDL-chol was weakly linked to CTAA (<jats:italic>χ</jats:italic><jats:sup>2</jats:sup>= 3.79;<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>= 0.052) and CCT (<jats:italic>χ</jats:italic><jats:sup>2</jats:sup>= 4.32;<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>= 0.038), while several other haplotypes were protective against both obesity and hLDL-chol level.</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Conclusion</jats:title><jats:p>Our results demonstrate that the genomic locus for the<jats:italic>MRAS</jats:italic>gene confers risk for CAD, obesity and dyslipidaemia and point to the possible involvement of other genes or regulatory elements at this locus, rather than changes in the M-Ras protein function, in these events.</jats:p></jats:sec>
publisher: Springer Science and Business Media LLC
